awd_titl_txt: Algebraic combinatorics: symmetric orbit closures and Schubert calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to construct combinatorial models. Combinatorial problems arise in many areas of mathematics and have applications that include optimization, computer science, and statistical physics. The central focus of this research is the study of polynomial equations that appear at the interface of the study of discrete mathematics, geometry, and symmetries. A key component of this project will be the training of students (high school, undergraduate, and graduate) and postdoctoral faculty. Thereby, we wish to help strengthen the STEM education and research infrastructure in the United States.

Earlier work of the investigator has led to precise connections of equivariant cohomology with spectra of Hermitian matrices, combinatorial commutative algebra with Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials, combinatorial K-theory with longest increasing subsequences in random words, and partition combinatorics with bibliometric indicators. Such examples motivate finding broader and more unified combinatorial laws, which is the goal of this project. This research will both deepen our understanding of such connections and help discover novel relationships.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant supported research, education and training in the field of algebraic combinatorics at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

During the period of the grant, the PI, together with graduate and undergraduate students connected the field with algebra, geometry and theoretical computer science. This included a solution to a decade old problem in Schubert calculus, the main scientific investigation of the grant. Another work introduced the study of saturated Newton polytopes, which has influenced the work of others in the field, see, e.g., the NSF CAREER public abstract of Karola Meszaros. The connection of this concept to computational complexity was also developed by the PI. Consequently, the PI gave the first polynomial time algorithm for the monomial coefficients of Schubert polynomials, an issue directly mentioned in the aforementioned abstract. One more research outcome of the grant introduced a new family of polynomials associated to K-orbits (which concern the mathematics of Kazhdan-Lusztig-Vogan polynomials; see the New York Times article "The Scientific Promise of Perfect Symmetry"). This work has had numerous follow ups by work of others; see, e.g., work of Zach Hamaker, Eric Marburg and Brendan Pawlowski. 

A number of early career scholars at Illinois were influenced by the mathematics of this grant. A doctoral student of the PI (Colleen Robichaux) earned an NSF graduate fellowship in 2017. Two graduated students (Oliver Pechenik and Anna Weigandt) are postdocs at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, one of the top institutions for algebraic combinatorics worldwide. A former postdoc Laura Escobar is a tenure track professor at Washington University St. Louis. Other former graduate students/postdocs now apply their mathematics training to US national defense. Anshul Adve, an undergraduate at UCLA who started working with the PI as a high school student was awarded a Goldwater fellowship in 2019 based on work from this grant. The grant also provided the resources to initiate ICLUE (Illinois Combinatorics Lab for Undergraduate Experience), a career long mentoring program directed by the PI. Numerous US students have already passed through the program, and a number of impactful publications have resulted. These scholars were aided by a steady flow of visiting mathematics also supported by this grant.

This National Science Foundation grant supported a vibrant field at  the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. It has touched the lives of many stages of mathematicians, from high school through graduate school, postdoctorial scholars, in addition to the PI.
